description: Borrowed from French char-à-bancs (literally “carriage with benches”).

entries.meaning: (Britain, historical) A horse-drawn, and then later, motorized omnibus with open sides, and often, no roof.
(Britain, old-fashioned) A bus, especially one hired by groups for pleasure outings, what was later called a coach.
(Britain, informal) A derisive term for a car, bus, train or other vehicle that is poor quality, slow or overcrowded.

verbs.description: charabanc (third-person singular simple present charabancs, present participle charabancing, simple past and past participle charabanced)

entries.meaning: (rare, transitive, intransitive) To travel or convey by charabanc.
